Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Inter-strain variation and evolution of resistance to phytochemicals in the bumblebee trypanosome parasite, Crithidia bombi
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animal pollination maintains ecosystem biodiversity and is valued at $215B/year to world agriculture. Bumblebees and other wild pollinators enable reproduction of wild plant species and contribute $3B/year to US food production; bumblebees may increase in importance if honeybee populations continue to collapse. However, parasites have contributed to US bumblebee population decreases of up to 96%. Plants produce an arsenal of chemicals, termed 'phytochemicals', that confer protection against herbivores and pathogens. These chemicals can be potent antimicrobials; they are used in traditional and modern medicines and confer herbs and spices with gustatory and food-preserving properties. Antimicrobial nectar chemicals consumed by bees could reduce pollinator infection, but might also select for bee parasites that are resistant to common chemicals, which would then lose medicinal value. This project will enhance understanding of how floral landscapes affect and could be manipulated to reduce pollinator disease.

This work will use a bumblebee parasite, Crithidia bombi, to determine how phytochemicals affect parasite growth and evolution, specifically: (1) Do strains vary in phytochemical resistance? Laboratory data suggest that effects of phytochemical ingestion depend on the parasite strain with which bees are infected. Such variation may reflect or allow differential strain fitness in response to common floral chemotypes. The proposed experiments will test the effects of 8 nectar phytochemicals on 4 C. bombi strains. (2) Can strains evolve resistance to individual phytochemicals? Chronic phytochemical exposure could select for tolerant genotypes, thereby reducing medicinal effects realized by pollinators. Experiments will evaluate whether growth-inhibiting effects of phytochemicals decrease over 4 weeks of phytochemical exposure. (3) Do phytochemical blends slow the evolution of resistance? In nature, pollinators encounter phytochemicals in blends rather than single compounds. In agricultural and clinical studies, evolution of resistance is delayed when parasites are simultaneously exposed to multiple chemicals, as would occur when bees forage in diverse landscapes. This project will test whether phytochemical resistance in C. bombi is retarded when the parasite is exposed to phytochemical blends rather than single compounds. Results will generate hypotheses about how plant interactions with animal pathogens influence pollinator health; and suggest strategies for using phytochemicals to mitigate pollinator decline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

Animal pollination supports biodiversity and is valued at $215B/year to world agriculture. Recent pollinator declines threaten ecosystem services, crop yields, and food security. Bumblebees and other wild pollinators enable reproduction of wild plant species and contribute $3B/year to US food production; bumblebees may increase in importance if honeybee populations continue to collapse. However, parasites have contributed to US bumblebee population decreases of up to 96%. Nectar consumed by bees contains antimicrobial phytochemicals thought to protect plants from their own pathogens. Such floral phytochemicals could reduce pollinator infection, but could also select for parasite resistance, which would diminish the medicinal value of phytochemicals. This project will enhance understanding of how floral landscapes affect-- and could be manipulated to mitigate-- pollinator disease.

Experiments

This work will used cell cultures of a bumblebee intestinal parasite, Crithidia bombi, to evaluate effects of phytochemicals on parasite growth and evolution, specifically:

(1) Do strains vary in resistance to phytochemicals?

(2) Can strains evolve resistance to phytochemicals?

(3) Do phytochemical combinations have stronger or weaker effects than predicted from their activities in isolation?

(4) How do complex mixtures of phytochemicals, such as bee pollen, affect parasite growth?

Results

Experiments showed that the bumble bee parasite Crithidia bombi has high levels of tolerance to most chemicals found in flowers. Only 3 of 9 tested phytochemicals resulted in meaningful growth inhibition. Levels of resistance varied across different parasite strains; some strains were more sensitive to particular phytochemicals than others. However, two common flower chemicals—thymol and eugenol—may be sufficient to inhibit growth of bee parasites at levels close to those that occur in flowers. This is exciting, because it suggests that plants could, via chemistry, influence spread of disease in pollinators. However, this antiparasitic activity is specific to particular chemicals.

Not only did parasites have initially high resistance. They also evolved even higher resistance when they were exposed to growth-inhibiting chemicals for long periods of time. This exposure favored cells with high chemical tolerance, and thereby selected for the evolution of chemical resistance. After 6 weeks of exposure, phytochemical concentrations that initially reduced growth by over 50% had hardly any effects on growth. In other words, over the course of a single growing season, parasites overcame the growth-reducing effects of chemicals. This was true whether the parasites were exposed to single chemicals or chemical mixtures. This result emphasizes the importance of variety in bee diets to prevent the evolution of resistance to particular phytochemicals. In contrast, a monotonous diet is likely to lead to the loss of any disease-reducing benefits of phytochemicals, because parasites can quickly evolve resistance to chemicals when there is strong selection to do so.

Combinations of flower chemicals also had stronger negative effects on parasite growth than was predicted based on the activities of individual chemicals. Although it is too early to generalize this result across all phytochemicals, experiments suggested that mixtures of phytochemicals could potentiate the effects of individual chemical components. Hence, a varied landscape may supply pollinators with not only a variety of nutrients, but also a variety of phytochemicals that could potentiate one another’s effects.

Effects of pollen itself on parasite growth were also tested. Although pollen is rich in plant chemicals that could have antimicrobial activities, it is also rich in nutrients, and parasites of bees are likely adapted to the antimicrobial chemicals that it contains. Pollen was found to improve—rather than inhibit—parasite growth. This finding indicates that pollen serves not only as a nutritional resource for pollinators, but also for their parasites, and that parasites are adapted to the potentially antimicrobial components in pollen.

This project shows that floral chemicals have antimicrobial activity, but that parasites of bumble bees have high resistance to many floral chemicals, including those in pollen. This work did, however, indicate that some chemicals occur in flowers at concentrations sufficient to reduce parasite growth, and suggests that these chemicals—which are found in plants of the mint family including rosemary, thyme, and oregano—could have beneficial effects on pollinators threatened by disease.

 

 Broader Impacts:

  • This project funded the training of a graduate student in cell culture techniques and fostered collaboration between the University of Massachusetts and Illinois State University, which will facilitate future projects related to pollinator health and conservation.
  • The co-PI mentored undergraduate students from under-represented groups, including female and transgender students, participated in mentorship training, and completed a teaching-as-research project to cultivate skills that will encourage future diversity in US science.
  • Results of experiments have the potential to improve pollinator health as well as understanding of host-pollinator ecology. Pollinator health is essential for agriculture as well as the perpetuation of multifloral natural landscapes containing diverse native species. Wild pollinators are important supporters of plant diversity, and study of their parasites should help develop ideas that indirectly support ecosystem services provided by pollinator-dependent plants.
